prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A single pointing on this galaxy to get the CO(2-1) line profile, or at least the total line flux

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity is set by the peak flux density, needing 4 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected). We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG.
One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(2-1) line at 13 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 8), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum, including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode, although we note that this is still likely to be a 2 sigma detection for our weakest source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A single pointing on this galaxy to get the CO(3-2) line profile, or at least the total line flux

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity is set by the peak flux density, needing 4 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected). We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG.
One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(3-2) line at 9 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 8), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum, including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode, although we note that this is still likely to be a 2 sigma detection for our weakest source.
The two pointings fill the 18 arcsec SPIRE beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A single pointing on this galaxy to get the CO(6-5) line profile

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity is set by the peak flux density, requesting 5 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected) as the estimates are bit more uncertain than for bands 3 and 4. We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG.
One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(5-4) line at 5 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 8), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum, including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode, although we note that we should get at leat a 3 sigma detection for our weakest source.
The pointings fill the SPIRE 18 arcsec beam: we need five of them to achieve that.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483 + 3508
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
A 7 pointing mosaic to fill the beam of one band 3 pointing on top of the SPIRE 250, plus one pointing on the BCG (galaxy 3508)
The CO(7-6) line at 306.25 GHz is included, just in case.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The aim here is to detect the dust continuum flux at the 5 sigma level, at the same (matching) angular resolution as the other bands.
We use non-standard continuum frequencies to include the CO(7-6) line, which might be detectable. The atmospheric transmission at these frequencies is also slightly better, resulting in slightly shorter integration times.
The pointings fill the SPIRE 18 arcsec beam, and some of the possible flux towards and including the BCG.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Over most of the cosmic history, rich galaxy environments such as galaxy clusters are places of little ongoing star formation. This trend is expected to reverse at high redshifts, however, when clusters and their constituent massive galaxies are forming, likely via interactions and mergers between massive, gas rich galaxies. A z=1.63 galaxy cluster from the SpARCs survey forms such an environment, for which we have 18 spectroscopically confirmed cluster members. One of these galaxies, in the core of this cluster, appears to be associated with a bright 250 micron source (most likely a blend of several fainter sources) detected by SPIRE on Herschel. It is also relatively close to the BCG, which is bright at 24 micron. We aim to resolve the confused SPIRE source in ALMA band 7 using seven pointings on and around the galaxy associated with it, and four adjoining pointings on the area towards and including the BCG. This will establish the origin of the 250 micron flux. In addition, we aim to measure the CO(2-1), CO(3-2) and CO(5-4) line fluxes (and possibly linewidths) to estimate the molecular gas mass and temperature of the SPIRE source(s), using ALMA band 3, 4 and 6 respectively.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00702.S, "The first glimpse of CO(2-1) in z=1.6 cluster galaxies", PI: Allison Noble Our band 3 science goal is very similar of theirs, but they go twice as deep, so we will retract our band 3 science goal (but not the other three) if proposal 2013.1.00702.S gets accepted.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00441.S, "An extreme galaxy in the core of a distant galaxy cluster", PI: Eelco van Kampen 2011.0.00430.S, "The evolution of molecular gas in high-z galaxies within rich cluster environments", PI: Allison Noble 2012.1.00491.S, "The first glimpse of CO(2-1) in z=1.6 cluster galaxies", PI: Allison Noble 2012.1.00495.S, "Molecular gas and dust in cluster galaxies at z=1.63: probing baryons in young cluster environments", PI: Ricardo Demarco
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
